results.title: Manyu-Wana 8
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Planting trees; reading of “The Bird and the Snake”, a story from Willowra; words for ‘few’ and ‘many’, using children onn the Willowra school bus; tracking, spearing and cookking kangaroo; bathing, working at the butcher’s; numbers and counting; traditional-style dance about the Easter story; chips magic. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 9
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Cleaning up the house; words for ‘slow’ and ‘fast’; pram magic; reading “The Emu and the Crane”, a traditional story about how the emu lost its wings; working at the clinic; words for ‘North’, ‘South’, ‘East’ and ‘West’; song about making playing humpies in a creek bed; making spinifex resin; maths: 5-2=3, using eggs. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: They took the children away: Aboriginal family experience
results.brief_description: Tens of thousands of Aboriginal children have been taken from their families. The removal of indigenous children has had devastating effects on the traditional family life of Aboriginal communities. Three Aboriginal people interviewed in this program talk about their own experiences in a hope to create awareness and understanding between Aboroginal and non-Aboriginal Australians.

results.title: Australian animals dreaming stories
results.brief_description: First Nations peoples used stories to teach their children about the laws and myths of their land. Pauline McLeod tells five stories about unique Australian animals. Each story is laced with colourful drawings. The stories featured are: ‘The Giant goanna and the black snake’; ‘The Platypus’; ‘How the kangaroo got its pouch’; ‘Why does the kookaburra laugh?’; ‘The Bunyip’.

results.title: Bridging the gap: the many worlds of Mandawuy
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Paolo Totaro hosts a discussion between Rhoda Roberts (Vox Populi), Sonia Voumard (The Age) and Mandawauy Yunupingu (teacher, musician, ambassador and father).
Mandawuy explores the ways he is bridging the gap between black and white culture through both his band Yothu Yindi, and as the Principal of the Yirrkala Community School in North East Arnhem Land, where, he devised the curriculum mix of First Nations peoples’ and western studies known as “Both Ways Education”.

results.title: Songlines: contemporary aboriginal music
results.creator_credit: John Foss, Richard Frankland, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.6. Contemporary Australian Aboriginal music has become an international presence in recent years. This program profiles artists who have taken their brand of indigenous music to the world: Yothu Yindi, Archie Roach and Tiddas. Traditional elements are incorporated into contemporary styles. This is not simply a matter of throwing in the odd didjeridu and clap stick, but rather the traditional cultural role of Aboriginal music as an educational medium is maintained and extended to cover new, important issues and themes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Foss, Richard Frankland, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions

results.title: Australian childhood: changes over 200 years
results.brief_description: Overviews childhood and adolescence in Australia from 1788 to 1990’s, using photographs, archival footage and printed material. Includes the topics of children’s work, access to education, children’s health, Aboriginal children, the impact of radio and TV, teenagers and consumerism and multi-cultural Australia. Provides a “potted view” of history from the perspective of children and their changing role in our society.

Provides a “potted view” of history from the perspective of children and their changing role in our society.

results.title: BeDevil
results.creator_credit: Tracey Moffatt, Anthony Buckley, Carol Hughes and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: BeDevil is an astounding work of Australian cinema which combines iconography drawn from Aboriginal culture and mythology, urban Australia, and popular culture. Comprising three ghost stories, all of which deal with the nature of memory and loss, this film playfully subverts the conventional linkings between aboriginality and spirituality. In “Mr. Chuck” the ghost of a US soldier haunts a billabong. In “Choo Choo Choo Choo” Ruby, (played by director Tracey Moffatt), and her family are haunted by an invisible train. In the final story, “Lovin’ The Spin I’m In”, a grieving Islander mother and her Greek-Australian neighbours are under the spell of the ghostly lovers, Bebe and Minnie. Drawing from influences that span across Aboriginal culture, American and European film, television and popular culture, “BeDevil” announces the birth of a new kind of Australian cinema: both indigenous and multicultural; mystical and sophisticated; innovative and pleasurable. The intoxicating cinematography is by Academy-award winning Geoff Burton and the music score is by Carl Vine. Visually stunning and metaphorically rich, this is a wonderful film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tracey Moffatt, Anthony Buckley, Carol Hughes and Southern Star Entertainment

results.title: Laurel Martyn
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
Laurel Martyn trained in London with Phyllis Bedells and was awarded a choreographic scholarship under the auspices of Ninette de Valois. In this interview, Martyn recalls the highlights of her performing career with the “Sadler’s Wells Ballet” in England and the “Borovansky Ballet” in Australia and discusses her teaching method and philosophy. Through her company, “Ballet Vistoria”, Martyn encouraged the development of a distinctively Australian style of dance and introduced ballet to thousands of school children. Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch.
